revision.text:
{{good article}} {{Infobox military person | honorific_prefix = [[General]] [[Sir]] | name = William Gabriel Davy | honorific_suffix = [[Royal Guelphic Order|KCH]] | image = File:Sir W Davy.jpg | image_size = 200px | alt = General Sir William Gabriel Davy | caption = General Sir William Gabriel Davy | birth_date = 1780 | birth_place = Kingsholm, [[Gloucestershire]] | death_date = 25 January {{death year and age|1856|1780}} | death_place = [[Tracy Park]], Gloucestershire | allegiance = {{plainlist| *{{flag|Kingdom of Great Britain}} (1797–1801) *{{flagcountry|UKGBI}} }} | branch = {{army|UK}} | serviceyears = 1797–1856 | rank = [[General (United Kingdom)|General]] | battles = [[Peninsular War]] *[[Battle of Roleia]] *[[Battle of Vimiera]] *[[Battle of Talavera]] | awards ={{plainlist| *[[Army Gold Medal|Field Officer's Gold Medal]] *[[Knight Commander of the Royal Guelphic Order]] }} }} [[General (United Kingdom)|General]] '''Sir William Gabriel Davy''', {{post-nominals|country=GBR|KCH}} (1780{{snd}}25 January 1856) was a [[British Army]] officer who fought in the [[Peninsular War]].
==Life==
[[File:Young Davy.jpg|thumb|left|200px|A miniature, of Davy as a young man, painted sometime before 1820.]] William Gabriel Davy was born in 1780 in Kingsholm, [[Gloucestershire]]. He was the eldest son of Major William Davy, Persian Secretary to [[Warren Hastings]], the first [[List of Governors of Bengal|Governor-General of Bengal]].<ref name="magazine">{{cite book|title=The Gentleman's Magazine and Historical Review|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=W7HPAAAAMAAJ&pg=PA423|year=1856|publisher=Bradbury, Evans|pages=423}}</ref><ref>[http://www.nam.ac.uk/online-collection/detail.php?acc=1981-01-22-1 "Major William Davy, Bengal Army, Persian Secretary to the Governor-General, in Persian dress, 1781 (c)"]. ''National Army Museum''. Retrieved 20 April 2015.</ref> Educated at [[Eton College]],<ref>{{Cite book|title = The Eton School Lists, from 1791 to 1850|last = Stapylton|first = H. E. C.|publisher = E. P. Williams|year = 1863|isbn = |location = London|pages = 16|url = https://books.google.co.uk/books?id=L80HAAAAQAAJ}}</ref><ref name="dnw">{{cite web|title=Orders, Decorations and Medals (27 – 28 June 2012): Lot 42|url=http://www.dnw.co.uk/auction-archive/catalogue-archive/lot.php?auction_id=254&lot_id=84237|website=dnw.co.uk|accessdate=21 February 2015}}</ref> Davy became a [[lieutenant]] in the [[61st Foot]] of the [[British Army]] in 1797. He transferred to the 5th battalion<ref name=dnw/> of the [[60th Foot]] at the beginning of 1802, and was made a [[Captain (armed forces)|captain]]. He was promoted to [[major]] and [[lieutenant-colonel]] on 5 February 1807 and 28 December 1809, respectively.<ref name=magazine/> After becoming the battalion's commander in May 1808,<ref name=dnw/> he led the battalion<ref name=magazine/> early in the [[Peninsular War]].<ref name=barton>{{cite web|title=General Sir William Davy (d.1856)|url=http://www.milesbarton.com/Sold_Items/General_Sir_William_Davy_d_1856__108.html|website=milesbarton.com|accessdate=21 February 2015}}</ref>
The battalion departed from [[Cork (city)|Cork]] on 12 July 1808.<ref name=dnw/> On 1 August, they arrived at [[Mondego Bay]] in [[Portugal]], where the first British troops to participate in the Peninsular War landed; Davy's battalion was the first to land.<ref name=dnw/><ref name=how>{{cite web|title=Battle of Rolica, 17 August 1808|url=http://www.historyofwar.org/articles/battles_rolica.html|website=historyofwar.org|accessdate=22 February 2015}}</ref> The [[Battle of Roleia]] was especially difficult, as Davy's battalion was in the middle of the fighting. At one point, the troops ascended a mountain "so covered with brushwood that [their] legs were ready to sink under [them]."<ref name=dnw/> In December 1809, just after being promoted to lieutenant-colonel, he moved to the regiment's 7th battalion.<ref name=barton/> However, he never participated in physical combat again.<ref name=dnw/> He married Mary Ann Carruthers in [[Adel, Yorkshire|Adel]], [[Yorkshire]] on 20 June 1814.<ref name=fs>{{cite web|title=William Gabriel Davy|url=https://familysearch.org/pal:/MM9.1.1/N2MG-7RM|website=familysearch.org|accessdate=25 February 2015}}</ref> In July 1830, Davy was made a [[major general]].<ref name=dnw/> He remarried in 1840, to the sister of [[Richard England (British Army officer)|Major-General Sir Richard England]], and was promoted to [[lieutenant-general]] in November of the following year.<ref name=magazine/> In November 1842, Davy became [[colonel]] of the 1st battalion of the 60th Foot. He was promoted to [[general]] in 1854.<ref name=magazine/><ref name=dnw/><ref name=barton/> From his purchase of the property in 1820, Davy resided at [[Tracy Park]], Gloucestershire.<ref name="Deeds">{{cite web |title=Deeds Relating to Tracy Park Estate |url=http://discovery.nationalarchives.gov.uk/details/rd/77f2135c-426f-41b6-bffd-a1ad155afa51 |publisher=The National Archives |accessdate=20 February 2015}}</ref> He died there on 25 January 1856, aged 77.<ref name=magazine/><ref name=dnw/>
==Honours== Davy was awarded the [[Army Gold Medal|Field Officer's Gold Medal]], a clasp, and a gold ribbon buckle for his service in the battles of [[Battle of Roleia|Roleia]], [[Battle of Vimiera|Vimiera]] and [[Battle of Talavera|Talavera]] during the Peninsular War. He was also praised by distinguished figures, such as Secretary of State [[Lord Castlereagh]].<ref name=dnw/> Davy became a [[Companion of the Bath]] in June 1815. [[King William IV]] [[knighted]] Davy and made him a [[Knight Commander of the Royal Guelphic Order]] in 1836.<ref name=magazine/><ref name=dnw/>
